Fidela's previous business is still existing and his husband is the one managing it, and Fidela having this sari sari store and just starting this business.

Miss.  Loem-eng N., 38, is single and lives with her parents, sisters and brothers in a village along National Road Number Six, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Loem-eng has been working in commune offices for ten years. She is asking for a loan of $1,200 to help her sister buy fruit to sell and provide capital for her father’s farming business.

loans.name: Munhzul

texts.en: Munhzul G. lives with her husband and two children in Hentiy province in Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband works as a businessman. She supports her family by operating a raw material trading business. She started her business in 2006 with working capital of 400,000 MNT and has grown it into a stable operation with working capital of over 2,000,000 MNT. She usually purchases her raw material from local markets or herders at a cheap price and sells back to the retailers at market price. Her earnings have enabled her to buy a new van for her business. In the future, she is planning to purchase a small car for her family. She is very hard-working woman and is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase livestock skins and grass.

loans.use: To purchase livestock skins and grass

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mr. Em O. and his wife (pictured) have been married since 1968 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home, two are garment-factory workers, one is a construction worker and another one attends school. 

Mr. Em O. works in the commune offices. His wife is a tailor. He is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorcycle for his son to ride to school.

loans.name: Minjuurdorj

texts.en: Minjuurdorj D. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hentiy province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife operates a sewing business in their home. He supports his entire family by operating an iron crafting business in his town. He produces and repairs a variety of chimneys, stovepipes, trunks, ger's ceilings and doors. He charges 40,000-50,000 MNT per door, 50,000 MNT per stove,  20,000-25,000 MNT per stovepipe, and 10,000 MNT per chest, respectively. His monthly income reached 400,000 and 500,000 MNT with a net profit of 200,000-300,000 MNT from 1997 until 2007. He started his iron craft business in 2006 and has grown it into a stable operation in a short time. With both his family businesses, they were able to build a new house where they will live. He usually purchases his raw materials from wholesale stores in the capital city of the province. He is a very hardworking man and is requesting a 500,000-MNT loan to purchase more iron.

loans.use: To purchase more iron

loans.name: Avil

texts.en:
Avil Z. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old. Avil is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Avil owns & operates a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Avil is just starting this business.

In 2010, Avil joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avil has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Avil is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Avil from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Akimhan

texts.en: Akimhan H. is 51 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. His family lives in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent). His wife sells meat in the Turlik market. Akimhan operates a taxi service in town. He first went into business in 2001, driving a taxi using his own small car, and has since built a successful and stable operation. His daily revenue is between 8,000 and 15,000 tugriks (MNT). His earnings have enabled him to buy a new truck for his son who is currently operating a transportation business as well. Akimhan is a very hardworking and friendly man. He says, "I am trying hard to earn enough money to build a new house for my children." He needs more funds to prepare for the upcoming winter; therefore, he is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan – both to purchase three tons of coal at 180,000 MNT and one trailer of bulk grass, as well as to repair his vehicle.

loans.use: To purchase three tons of coal and one trailer of bulk grass

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose M. is 28 years old, married and has four children. Her eldest is 11 years old and the youngest is 5 years old. She joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a partner MFI of Kiva in the Philippines, to have capital to start a business. Now she is so proud that she became a member of ASHI because, aside from now being financially independent from her husband’s income, her confidence has improved as a consequence of attending weekly meetings and meeting different people. Today she is one proud mother because her earnings have helped pay for their daily expenses and the allowances of their children for going to school. Her husband is also happy because they were able to renovate their house.

This time, Mary Rose is applying for additional capital of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) for her variety store. She will buy more sacks of rice to sell to her customers, as well as soft drinks and assorted grocery products. Her business plan is to earn more and increase her capital so she can have more stock to sell and earn more profit. Since rice is in demand by her customers, she wishes to increase the volume of her stock. All her goals will be achieved if ASHI and Kiva will give their complete support and trust in her capability to manage her business. In return, she will insure diligence in performing her tasks as a member and the mother of her children. Her husband and children will always serve as her inspiration to do her best in managing the business.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, soft drinks and assorted grocery products

loans.name: Gohar

texts.en:
Gohar Y. is 35 years old. She lives in Vanadzor city with her husband and two children. 

For about five years, Gohar has run a clothes-trading business. She purchases merchandise from Georgia and Turkey and resells it in her own shop in Vanadzor city. Gohar’s husband helps her a lot in her business and with the income from trading, they maintain their family. 

Gohar seeks a 450,000 Armenian Drams loan to buy autumn and winter season clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy autumn and winter season clothes to resell

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta P. is 53 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Del Pilar in the municipality of Cabatuan in Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Julieta runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first, of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Annbelle

texts.en:
Annbelle P. is 46 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Del Pilar in the municipality of Cabatuan in Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Annbelle makes and sells fish balls, other dim sums, corn bits and legumes such as peanuts and green peas for snacks to the local community. Annbelle is just starting this business.

In 2010, Annbelle joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Annbelle is requesting a loan, her first, of 5000 PHP that will be used to buy additional inventory and add to her working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Batsuuri

texts.en:
Batsuuri O. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife stays at home to take care of their little children.

Batsuuri operates a grocery business in his town. He provides his customers with potatoes which he plants and harvests himself. This year he was able to harvest six tons of potatoes. Batsuuri started his grocery business in 2006 and has gained a lot of experience. His monthly business profit is between 80,000 and 100,000 MNT. He uses his earnings to provide for his family.

In the future Batsuuri hopes for continued success and to increase the types of vegetables that he grows. He is requesting a 200,000 MNT loan to purchase more vegetables such as cabbages, beets and carrots for his grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Peter Mugi

texts.en:
Peter Mugi is a 42-year-old businessman who offers private transport services to people in Karangu, Kikuyu. He has been in this business for five years. He is married to Hannah Wambui, who is a farmer, and together they are blessed with three children, ages 19, 17 and 10 years respectively.

He has never borrowed from any MFI (microfinance institution) and he was introduced to KADET LTD. by Joseph N’gethe, one of the members of a group of KADET clients. He is applying for his first loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to use to diversify his business into farming by buying a dairy cow for milk production. This kind of business is very marketable in this area.

He hopes to grow his business in the future to boost his income-generating activities to enable him to cater to his family's basic needs.

loans.use: To use to diversify the business into farming by buying a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta A. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Tuburan, Brgy. Cambaog, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a pottery business. Her husband Vicente A., 45, works as a pottery maker to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business. They have four children between 5 and 20 years old. 

Marietta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marietta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 29,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 15,000 PHP, thus raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing 29,500 PHP which she intends to use to purchase more materials for her pottery making business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and do home repairs. Marietta A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase materials

He used to operate a transportation service, using his micro bus from 2000 to 2005. He has been operating a cafe with help of his wife for past five years. Over the years, he has worked hard to build a stable operation and hopes to continue success in his growing business. Jamsran is a modest and very motivated man and says, "All I want is to open my own big restaurant in the future."

loans.name: Baku

texts.en:
Baku H. is 31 years old and lives with his mother, wife and two sons in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife works as a salesperson and has a monthly salary of 70,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). 

Baku currently operates a taxi service in his town. He has been engaged in this business since 2007 and has built a successful and stable operation in a short time. Moreover, he also transports a variety of raw materials in addition to his taxi service. He hopes to buy new truck and start a transportation business in the future. 

With the help of his business, he was able to improve his family's standard of living. For the future, he says, "I am planning to save enough money for my children's future education." 

Baku is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to repair his truck as well as to purchase grasses at 500,000 MNT and three tons of coals for winter preparation.

texts.en: Bayanjargal D. is a widow who lives with her adult aged daughter in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She and her daughter live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She has 5 children who are 21 to 36 years old. She has 1 child who already has a family while the other 3 children are working and helping her out.

With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Lilia P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Magsarjalam

texts.en: Magsarjalam D. is 50 years old. He lives with his wife and one son in Huvsgul, a province of Mongolia, in their own ger, a traditional nomadic tent home. His wife is a teacher and is currently retired. Magsarjalam makes furniture for the local community. He started this business in 1980 and has since made quality furnishings for the people of his town. He produces various kinds of wood items and hopes to build a broad customer base. Currently, his earnings are the only source of income for his family, so he is focusing on expanding his business in order to improve his family’s financial situation. With almost 30 years of owning his own business, Magsarjalam has not only gained experience and knowledge in making quality furniture products, but he has also gained business knowledge. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy more timber to make the wood used in gers and to buy furniture-making supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy timber and furniture-making supplies

loans.name: Ma. Paz

texts.en:
Ma. Paz C. is a 49-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 1 business venture: fishing/fish vending business. She lives in Brgy. Manalongon, Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing/fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP12,000.

Ma. Paz is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Ma. Paz aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Bahodir

texts.en:
G. Bahodir is a farmer. He grows onions, potatoes, and other vegetables to support his family. He is 37 years old and has three children. He is worried about earning enough money to sustain his 1-hectare farm. His wife supports him in all his decisions. Together, they work hard to raise their children well. He has been tilling the land for 12 years. Bahodir is asking for a loan of 4000 Somoni that will be used to buy more seeds and fertilizer. The loan will enable him to have an abundant harvest.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It hosted a key post along the Silk Road and marked the extent of Alexander the Great's empire. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The country's civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients present viable business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Johnita

texts.en:
Johnita D. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Sumaliring, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: fish vending and food vending businesses. Her husband Obaldo D., who is 46 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who are 12 to 22 years old.

Johnita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Johnita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 which she intends to use to as additional working capital so that she could continue to save up for the future of her children's education and family. Johnita D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia V. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela, Philippines. She is 55 years old. Nelia is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nelia owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making glutinous rice cakes, ice cold snack (mixed fruits with milk & sugar) and other delicacies for sale. Nelia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2008, Nelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nelia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital for food business

loans.name: Ma. Wenilyn

texts.en: Ma. Wenilyn K. is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a cosmetology business. She lives in Brgy. 3, Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her cosmetology business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,500 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ma. Wenilyn is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can purchase new equipment. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Wenilyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.use: Purchase of new equipment

loans.name: Johnny & Pokah Bakery Group

texts.en:
John C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of two borrowers, called the "Johnny & P. Bakery." John is 45 years old, is married, and has one child who is eighteen years old. He was only able to attend school through twelfth grade due to financial constraints. He cares for two siblings.

For the past sixteen years, John has been operating a bakery in New Kru Town in Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his half (15,000 Liberian dollars) of the business loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, butter, yeast, and so forth. He describes himself as a determined man whose goal is to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, butter, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie D. is a new member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a partner MFI (microfinance institution) of Kiva in the Philippines. Determined to improve their standard of living, she joined ASHI. She also believed that by joining she does not only have access to capital but can also further be empowered by good values and principles. She will meet new friends as well. 

She used her first loan to begin a business buying and selling Ready-to-Wear clothes (RTW) and assorted personal products. For her second loan, she is applying for 9,500.00 Philippine pesos as additional capital for her business. She wants to buy more stock, especially now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. 

She is planning to buy more RTW clothes, toys and other gift items for her customers. This additional capital will earn her more profit that can help her husband with their daily financial needs. 

Her dream is to be able to provide quality educations for their four children until they finish college and earn a degree. As of now, her eldest is 12 years old and the youngest is 5 months old. Three of her children are in grade school. The couple has started saving for the future of their children and with this new additional capital, they can increase their savings as well. She is hopeful that ASHI and Kiva will continue their partnership in providing financial assistance to her until she reaches her goals.

loans.use: To buy additional Ready-to-Wear clothes, toys, gift items

loans.name: Hasankhon

texts.en: Hasankhon is a hard-working farmer because he knows that the only way he can support and provide for his loved ones is through hard work and dedication. Consequently, he leaves home every day at dawn to work on his farm and to look after his cattle. Hasankhon wishes to expand his business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and young cattle. That is the reason that he is asking for a loan. He will always cherish the memory of all those who gave him a helping hand when he needed it by granting him his request. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer and young cattle in order to expand the business

loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm oil and caustic for the soap production

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en: Gulbahor K. is 40 years old. Her husband currently is working in Russia. Gulbahor is a devoted mother who struggles day after day to provide the best for her family. Ten years ago, she got an idea to start raising the cattle to contribute to the family finances, taking advantage of the space she had available in her house for this business. Slowly, the number of cows increased and with them, her clients started asking for more and more. With an endless list of requests, Gulbahor has finally decided to increase the number of livestock she keeps and for this reason she is requesting a loan of $1,500. loans.name: Gani

texts.en: O. Gani, aged 42 years, is married with three children, all of them in school through the universal primary education program. Gani earns his living through agriculture, specifically planting rice and corn and also breeding cattle. He seeks room for expanding the business and creating an opportunity for his market, especially during the times he is waiting to harvest. He needs an alternative that can help him save for his children's higher education. Gani requests a 4,000 Somoni loan that he will spend for purchasing young cattle. loans.name: Baatarchuluun

texts.en:
Baatarchuluun L. lives with his wife in Hentiy province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. His wife is currently unemployed. The couple has a two children who are both grown up and live on their own. 

Baatarchuluun operates a transportation service using his own truck. He delivers a variety of loads for individuals and organizations. During the fall season, he transports wheat for a flour company. He has been engaged in this business since 2005 and has had much success. 

In the future, he hopes to continue making progress with his business and says, "I will keep on doing my best." He is requesting a 550,000 MNT loan to purchase two wheels for his truck.

loans.use: To purchase two wheels for his truck

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes to sell

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros G. is a married woman who lives in Purok 6, Barangay Giligan, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She and her husband earn their living by operating two business ventures, a general store and an herbal medicine dealership. Milagros operates the general store and her husband, Papias Geromal, who is 34 years old, is an herbal medicine dealer. They have three children who are between the ages of 5 months and 14 years old. 

Milagros joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Milagros and her husband have been incrementally lifting their family out of poverty by the sweat of their brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $280, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more stock to sell in her general store. She also wants to use part of the money to purchase a motorcycle to use for the business. She and her husband want to earn more money in order to save up for the future education of their children. Milagros G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. was born in 1968. She lives in Ijevan city with her husband. Her two children are already married and live separately from their parents.
 
She and her husband run their own business in a rented shop, where they sell food and household goods. Thanks to their business income they have been able to support their family, and they paid for their children's education, organized their children’s weddings and bought a car for their business.
 
Susan is seeking a 500,000 AMD loan to buy juice, sacks of rice, macaroni, vermicelli, etc. for her shop.

loans.use: To buy juice, sacks of rice, macaroni, vermicelli, etc. for her shop

loans.name: Roberosa

texts.en:
Roberosa N. is a 34-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a general store, a fishing business and a transportation business. She lives in Purok Litid, Barangay Manalongon, Santa Catalina, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $230. 

Roberosa is now borrowing 13,000 PHP so that she can do some repairs and maintenance on her motorcycle as well as buy stock to sell in her general store. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. 

Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Roberosa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg T. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hentii province in Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Both of her two daughters attend a local school. 

Ganchimeg operates a second hand goods trading business. She began her business in 2008 with a working capital of 400,000 MNT by purchasing a variety of second hand clothes from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, which she sold in a rented outdoor stall at the Undurhaan, one of the main trade centers in the province. 

Over the past two years, Ganchimeg has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 1,400,000 MNT today. For the future, she plans to expand her business by increasing her working capital. She is a talkative and hardworking woman and is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more clothing for her second hand goods trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more crates of Liquor

loans.name: Gansuh

texts.en:
Gansuh C. lives with his wife and daughter in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. He lives with his family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife works as an accountant in the department of National Security Agency while his daughter is a teacher in the local school.

He operates a taxi service in his town. He began his business in 2006, and at first he was driving a small car of the Excel brand. With his earnings, he was able to upgrade his previous car into his latest and more convenient car, a Sonata. In the four years of running his taxi service, he has gained a good professional reputation among the people of his town as a safe, reliable driver. 

Gansuh would eventually like to buy a larger, more comfortable car, an Istana, so that he can transport more people across longer distances, which would increase his profits. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to repair his car's engine.

loans.use: To repair his car's engine

loans.name: Gombo

texts.en:
Gombo T. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and teenage son in a traditional housing tent called a ger, in Uvurhangai province, central Mongolia. His son, age 13, attends a local secondary school. Since 2000, he has been operating a dairy products and milk business in a rented stall at the Zanabazar trade center and since then he has built a very successful and stable operation. His business has quickly grown and he has earned enough money to purchase a  new shop in 2007 where he operates two businesses; dairy products and selling meat. 

He usually purchases his meats from the countryside at cheaper prices to sell at market price. He hopes to continue growing his business and build his own grocery store in the future. Gombo is a very diligent man. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase and stock dairy products such as milk, dried curds and cheese, clotted cream etc, when wholesale prices are lower in the summertime.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
Ulugbek E. is an optimistic and positive person who works to build a prosperous future for his children and maintain their lifestyle. Ulugbek is 44 years-old and a citizen of Kyrgyz's southern city, Osh. He graduated from industrial college and worked as a mechanical engineer at a brick factory. But the money which Ulugbek earned working  around the clock, didn’t cover the needs of his family of three children. In 1994, with the wholehearted support of his wife, who worked as a teacher at the local school, Ulugbek decided to start his business selling office supplies. Using their money, which they put away for a rainy day, this couple began to sell office suppliers and bags at the local market. Due to strong efforts and hard work, Ulugbek managed to buy a house and a used car for his family. His conscientious attitude to work allowed him to gain a reputation of being a responsible businessman. 

But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh, Ulugbek lost his business. His sales shop at the market was robbed and looted. But Ulugbek didn’t give up and decided to resume his lost business and continue his activities. For this very reason, Ulugbek is applying for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which he needs to restart his business. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase office supply goods for retail sales

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
"Gilda A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Maligaya, Brgy. Magara, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures:   buying & selling "pawid" made of nipa,  buying & selling fish and a general store businesses.  Her husband Ferdinand A., who is 40 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 6 children who are 3 to 20 years old. 

Gilda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gilda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 9th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she could continue to save up for the future education of her children and fulfill her plans of buying a photocopying machine. 

Gilda A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Mammy Group

texts.en:
In the photo are the two members of the “Mammy” group. They are small-scale businessmen based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 2,000,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mohamed F..  Mohamed is age thirty-five; he was born in Makeni where he is currently residing together with his wife and six children. His wife is a businesswoman. Three of their children are attending primary school and three are in secondary school. For eighteen years now, he has been selling used clothes. With this loan, he will buy used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy used clothes for resale

loans.name: Courageous Men And Women Group

texts.en:
Rachel S. who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Courageous Men And Women. She is 35 years old married and has three children and the youngest is 1 year old. She is a college student. She describes herself as a kind and polite woman.

For 4 years she has been selling rice, oil, pepper, salt, tomatoes, onions etc. in Redlight Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 26,000 LRD group loan to buy more rice, oil, pepper, salt, tomatoes, onions etc. Her goals are to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, pepper, salt, tomatoes, onions etc

loans.name: Thank You Jesus Group

texts.en:
Isatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Isatu was born in Makeni city about thirty-two years ago. She is married to a soldier and the couple has five children, two in secondary school and three in primary school.

For twenty years now, Isatu has been selling market food – palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), salt, Maggi (cubes used to give sauce a sweet taste), and poultry. This is the second loan that  Isatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this new loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and further improve their living conditions. 

Isatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business; she will buy palm oil, salt, Maggi cubes and poultry in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy palm oil, salt, Maggi and poultry in large quantity

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more dozens of lappas ( a traditional dress for women), flour, sugar, baking powder, yeast etc

loans.name: Jane Wathua

texts.en:
Jane Wathua M. has been in this farming activity for seven years in Mwimto; Kikuyu area. She sell milk directly to customers who uses the milk for daily consumption. Her monthly income is Kshs.90, 000. She is 46 years old and married to Edward, 48 years old, who is a farmer.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and she is applying for her fifth loan of Kshs.50, 000, after repaying her previous loan successfully. She plans to use this loan to buy another dairy cow so that she is able to increase her milk supplies, and get better income.

Jane hopes to grow her business and supply milk in large scale to dairy companies in Mwimto and it’s surroundings’.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow  to increase  her milk supplies

loans.use: To buy more supplies of glass bowls

loans.name: Sincerity Group

texts.en:
Kou S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Sincerity.  She is 28 years old single, and has one child who is 8 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficult. She cares for two siblings.

For 4 years, she has been selling dried fish in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 25,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of fish. 

She describes herself as a very hard-working woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Allah Thantho Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Allah Thontho” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mariatu K.. Mariatu is twenty-seven; she was born in Makeni, where she is currently residing together with her husband and four children. Her husband is a petty trader; two of her children are attending primary school and two are not of school-going age. Mariatu has been a businesswoman for four years now. She sells dishes, plastic bowls and cloth. Mariatu is requesting for this loan in order to improve her business size and quality. She will use the loan to buy the above-mentioned items to add to her current inventory.

loans.use: Buys dishes, plastic bowls and cloth

loans.name: Roza

texts.en:
Roza K. is 44 years old and was born in the village 8-March, where she still lives today. She graduated from secondary school, but could not continue her studies because she had to help her family in the household. When she was 19, she got married and became the mother of four children.

In 1990, in order to provide her children with essentials, Roza started her business in cattle breeding. She worked hard and managed to broaden her business and enlarge the number of cattle to five cows, seven sheep, eighteen goats and five horses. With the revenues, Roza was able to pay for higher education for her elder son.

Roza plans to use the loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing calves. With the revenues from this investment, she plans to apply all efforts to make her dream comes true – to see her children educated and progressive.

Bai-Tushum and Partners, one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan, uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more sugar, oil, salt, tomatoes, rice, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Favorite Partners Group

texts.en:
Annie J., shown holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Favorite Partners. She is 26 years old, engaged, and has a one-year-old child. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints.

For 2 years, Annie has been selling fried plantain in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia, and plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 25,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bunches of plantain. She describes herself as a trustworthy woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of plantain

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, gallons of red oil, pepper, salt, onions, seasoning, etc

loans.name: Trust In God Group

texts.en:
Fatmata K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatmata was born in Buya Romende village, about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children, two of whom are attending secondary school and two in primary school. 

For many years now, Fatmata has been selling market foodstuffs such as salt, rice, bulgur wheat, etc.  With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business, make more sales and consequently improve her living conditions. She will use her share of the loan (SLL 1,000,000) to buy salt, rice and bulgur wheat wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy salt, rice and bulgur wheat wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Concern Women #2 Group

texts.en:
Ruth B., shown holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Concern Women #2. She is 33 years old, married, and has seven children. She is a sophomore college student.

For two years, Ruth has been selling radio batteries, sugar, milk, rice, etc. in Rehab Community outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more batteries, sugar, milk, rice etc. Ruth describes herself as a respectful woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more radio batteries, sugar, milk, rice, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: as working capital for his mechanics business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet M. is a married woman who lives in Purok Centro, Bgy.4, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: canteen and farming businesses. Her husband Jose M., who is 62 years old, works as a cook in their canteen to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are 18 to 32 years old.

 Juliet joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Juliet has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 60,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to pay for more raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future to get into the pig-raising business. 

Juliet M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.use: To buy more soap, plastic bags, milk, cigarettes, liquor, etc.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza G. is a 21-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: gardening and a business buying and selling vegetables. She lives in Prk. Masayawan, Brgy. Dumarao, Roxas, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her gardening and vegetables businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,800. Liza is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she  can purchase fertilizers and use the rest of the loan as additional capital.  This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. 

Liza aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Red Lion Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Red Lion” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Binta F.. Binta was born in the village of Gbembembu near Makeni. She is thirty-five years old. She is married to a businessman and they have four children, two of whom are attending secondary schools.

Binta sells provisions – milk, sugar, butter, etc. She also sells salt and toiletries. Binta will use her share of the loan to buy more goods to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy milk, sugar, butter, salt, toiletries, etc.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores E. is a 47-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying & selling vegetables and food vending businesses. She lives in Prk. Masaya, Brgy. Magara, Roxas, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her vegetables and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. Dolores is borrowing PHP 14,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Dolores aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita C. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Maligaya, Brgy. Magara, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store.

Her husband, Sonny C., who is 52 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children, who are 19 to 26 years old and all have their own families. 

Lolita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to have something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lolita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus lifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future and use it as additional capital for the business. Lolita C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Hortencia  Nelson

texts.pt:
Hortência Nelson M. nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, mãe de 5 filhos maiores de idade. Fez somente 7ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa de aluguer com seus filhos e ainda sustenta sua mãe que vive com ela.

Saiu de Gaza para Maputo com a sua mãe ainda muito nova. Trabalha numa empresa como contratada ha mais de 3 anos, tem um salario mensal de 2.850.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum de vez enquanto na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pregos, pedra, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência de forma a sair da casa de aluguer.

O seu sonho é poder concluir a sua casa para poder viver na casa própria com a sua família. Esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir sua obra.
texts.en:
Hortencia Nelson M. was born in the district of Manjacaze, in the province of Gaza in the south of Mozambique. She has 5 grown children. She only studied through 7th grade, and didn't continue because of a lack of financial resources. She lives with her children in a rented house and helps support her mother, who lives with them.

Hortencia left Gaza for Maputo with her mother when she was still quite young. She has worked on contract for a business for more than 3 years, with a monthly salary of 2850 Meticais. She uses this income to cover household expenses and occasionally saves some in her bank account as well.

Hortencia has never taken out a loan with another bank. She found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva Field Partner] through friends who also work with the institution. This is her 1st loan, for the amount of 10,000 Meticais. She plans to use this money to buy construction materials (cement, bricks, stone, sand and other items) in order to continue working on the construction of her home and move out of the house she is renting.

Hortencia's dream is to finish with the construction and live in her own home with her family. She is confident that she will be able to repay the loan as indicated and take out another loan to finish the job.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, bricks, stone, sand and other items)

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia M. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Maligaya, Brgy. Magara, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: vinegar processing and buying and selling of dried fish. 

Her husband, Eduardo M., who is 51 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 23 to 25 years old. 

Delia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to have something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,100, thus lifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for the business so she could continue to save up for their future and buy a sewing machine for an additional business. Delia M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: food vending/processing and buying and selling of ginger. She lives in Prk. Maligaya, Brgy. Magara, Roxas, Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending/processing and ginger businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,240. 

Yolanda is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Yolanda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.
